Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity for 21st Century Social Sciences; Washington, D.C., Spring, 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will bring together experts to address a national program of capacity building for dynamic and transformed social sciences. It responds to a growing need across multiple scientific disciplines, policy making institutions, and private enterprise for a richer understanding of complex human social systems. Such a program will provide a more thorough scientific assessment of risks and uncertainties in social policies, including unexpected and, especially, undesirable policy consequences. It will also help to better anticipate the potential for rapid and disruptive change (i.e., tipping points and phase changes) that are characteristic of complex systems. Building significant capacity in transdisciplinary science, and employing advanced technologies to understand the dynamics of human society, will promote United States leadership in basic and applied research on the social dimensions of the grand challenges we face in the twenty-first century.

Workshop participants will be charged with developing a roadmap for building national capacity in the social sciences that is needed to meet global challenges facing our world and society in the twenty-first century. There are important scientific problems pertaining to the organization and dynamics of human social systems that are of such scale and complexity that they are intractable to individual researchers, and require a community-scale research organization. The challenges of a world in which human actions are significant drivers of earth systems requires a global-scale science of human society to lead interdisciplinary research by collaborative teams that span social, behavioral, and natural sciences. It requires advanced concepts and methods to manage, synthesize, and model data at the size and complexity needed to match human socio-ecological systems, and computational tools to process the vast quantities of information being generated and captured by these systems today. The rapid pace of technological and social change that is transforming both the domesticated earth and its human managers in unprecedented ways demands an equally dramatic transformation of social science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant primarily supported a planning meeting (March 19-20, 2015) to bring together scientists who broadly represent the diversity of the social/behavioral science community. The participants were charged with developing a roadmap for building national capacity in the social/behavioral sciences that is needed to meet global challenges facing our world and society in the twenty-first century. This grant also supported to a limited extent, and catalyzed to a greater extent numerous followup activities to communicate with an even wider array of researchers across the social and natural sciences.  


In the nearly two years, since the initial Washington planning meeting, the investigators in this award, and the network of collaborators that has grown out of the activities that emerged from that meeting have worked to raise awareness of the need to build significant new capacity in next generation human systems science, that encompasses and extends beyond current social/behavioral science disciplines. This has brought a widening community of practitioners into an evolving conversation of how to accomplish this.
The issues discussed and recommendations proposed by the initial planning meeting have received broad support in the many venues where presented and discussed by social/behavioral scientists, natural scientists, modelers, government agencies, and international organizations. In these conversations, there is very strong consensus about the urgency for next generation science of human systems, and value of applying new technologies and exploring new conceptual frameworks to develop this. Importantly, the idea of a national center to help catalyze next generation human system science also has wide and strong support across these communities.  


These conversations have also helped to identify multiple potential routes toward new capacity in the science of human systems. Likewise, participants in these conversations have helped to explore these alternatives, including the potential applications of new data science methods and modeling, and an expanding array of possible funding vehicles beyond NSF--including other federal agencies, private foundations, a Congressional commission, and international organizations.  


Two key documents summarize the ideas and recommendations that have been generated in the course of this grant:  


A white paper, initially submitted to NSF that can be downloaded at: https://www.academia.edu/27189352/A_National_Center_for_Human_Systems_Science_Advancing_Next_Generation_Social_Informatics_and_Analytics

A set of comments to the Congressional Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking that can be downloaded at: https://www.regulations.gov/document?D=USBC-2016-0003-0186
